'Stanley Kubrick' (; July 26, 1928 â March 7, 1999) was an American film
director, screenwriter, producer, cinematographer, and editor who did most of
his work as an expatriate in the United Kingdom. He is regarded as one of the
greatest filmmakers of all time. His films, typically adaptations of novels or
short stories, are noted for their "dazzling" For example,  and unique
cinematography, attention to details to achieve realism and an inspired use of
music scores. Kubrick's films covered a variety of genres, including war, crime,
romantic and black comedies, horror, epic and science fiction. Kubrick was also
noted for being a perfectionist, using painstaking care with scene staging and
working closely with his actors.

Starting out as a photographer in New York City, he taught himself all aspects
of film production and directing after graduating from high school. His earliest
films were made on a shoestring budget, followed by one Hollywood blockbuster,
[[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]], after which he spent most of the rest of his
career living and filming in the United Kingdom. His home at Childwickbury Manor
in Hertfordshire (north of and near to London) became his workplace where he did
his writing, research, editing and management of production details. This
allowed him to have almost complete artistic control, but with the rare
advantage of having financial support from major Hollywood studios.

Many of his films broke new ground in cinematography, including [[2001: A Space
Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]] (1968), a science-fiction film which
director Steven Spielberg called his generation's "big bang," with innovative
visual effects and scientific realism. Giulio Angioni, Fare dire sentire:
l'identico e il diverso nelle culture (2011), p. 37 and Un film del cuore, in Il
dito alzato (2012), pp. 121â136 For [[Barry Lyndon]] (1975), Kubrick
obtained lenses developed by Zeiss for NASA in order to film scenes under
natural candlelight and [[The Shining (film)|The Shining]] (1980) was among the
first feature films to make use of a Steadicam for stabilized and fluid tracking
shots. As with his earlier shorts, Kubrick was the cinematographer and editor on
the first two of his thirteen feature films. He directed, produced and wrote all
or part of the screenplays for nearly all his films.

While some of Kubrick's films were controversial with mixed reviews, such as
[[Paths of Glory]] (1957), [[Lolita (1962 film)|Lolita]] (1962), and [[A
Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]] (1971), most of his films were
nominated for either Oscars, Golden Globes or BAFTAs, and were later acclaimed
as being masterpieces. Film historian Michel Ciment considers his films to be
"among the most important contributions to world cinema in the twentieth
century." One writer states that "Kubrick is a legend in
every sense of the word, and is one of the most influential, shocking, and well-
respected men in the history of film," Rossi, Danielle. [http://www.dailytargum.com/inside_beat/film/director-spotlight-stanley-
kubrick/article_4e97a6f0-39e2-11e2-a89f-001a4bcf6878.html "Director Spotlight:
Stanley Kubrick"], Daily Targum, Rutgers University, Nov. 29, 2012 while
director Norman Jewison calls him one of the "great masters" that America has
ever produced. [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XyxueyHqZeE Interview with
Norman Jewison], American Film Institute, Feb. 1, 2013
